transcripts.text: This is Susan Bassey, and as we're growing accustomed to police officers being filmed in public these days, there are some places where we are not allowed to film the police, including this family courthouse in Santa Clara County, the heart of Silicon Valley.  This is the security video taken from the day that a Santa Clara County Sheriff Deputy, Officer Gomez, sees my phone, broke my hand, and then unlawfully searched my phone.  The Santa Clara County District Attorney, who is charged with public corruption investigations and prosecutions and charged with investigating the police and prosecuting bad police officers, elected not to prosecute any of the nine police officers who were present this day.  Instead, he has spent three years, 29 hearings, and five judges prosecuting me for taking a photograph and recording police inside a public courthouse.  And you might begin to ask yourself what it could be that the judges and the lawyers in this county don't want us to see.
We're going to the bridge concert in Mountain View, which is a wonderful music, you know, 60s music.

A year ago, the Santa Clara County District Attorney, Jeff Rosen, filed a declaration in a civil case where he said that he was so frightened of me that he now needs taxpayers to fund this guy, an investigator for the DA's office who is an armed bodyguard, armed and standing by to protect Mr.  Rosen from me because Mr.  Rosen is more fearful of me than he is of the terrorists.  the white-collar criminals, the rapists, the murderers, and the child abusers in Santa Clara County.

Well, with over two million people in jail, the U.S.  has the world's biggest prison population.  But some are seeing the inside of a cell because dodgy judges are getting payback from the private sector.  RT's Guy Naitre-Chican reports on those dishing out justice for a fee.

Two Pennsylvania judges have made a killing out of juvenile prisons.  Mark Chivarella and Michael Conahan were convicted of receiving kickbacks for more than two million dollars from the developers of several private detention centers.  But the real crime, according to parents, is that these judges then sent more than 5,000 children to those very facilities for crimes as small as fighting on a school bus or posting a parody of their teacher on the web.
